Title:
Aspergillus jilinensis sp. nov. and its thermostable alkaline
enzymes evaluation
Keywords:
alkali-tolerant, Aspergillus section Terrei, enzyme,
multi-gene phylogeny
Abstract:
Aspergillus comprises a diverse group of species, which
have a ubiquitous distribution and occur on decaying vegetation, soil,
and dust. During an investigation of the diversity of alkali-tolerant or
alkalophilic fungi in China, two isolates producing columnar conidial
heads with globose conidia belonging to Aspergillus are isolated from
the soda soil and named as Aspergillus jilinensis. Its phylogenetic
position is determined by analysis of a dataset of the combined gene
fragments including the nuclear ribosomal internal transcribed spacer
(ITS) region, beta-tubulin (BenA) gene, and calmodulin (CaM) genes. The
morphology and culture characteristics of this fungus are described.
Distinctions between the new species and its close relatives are
discussed. Aspergillus jilinensis is phylogenetically clustered with A.
alabamensis, but it differs from the latter by producing smaller and
fewer conidia. Additionally, colonies of A. jilinensis present light
buff-colored on MEA and bright golden yellow color on CYA. Meanwhile,
the enzyme activity assays show that α-amylase, endo-protease, and
endo-β-1, 4-xylanase of A. jilinensis are thermostable in an alkaline
reaction system, responding to alkali-tolerant characteristics,
indicating a potential alkali-tolerant enzyme candidate. This study
updates our knowledge of species diversity of alkali-tolerant
Aspergillus.
